Shawn Blanchard is a 46 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last visit 03/07/2025 after this he had ultrasound 3/2025 and fibroscan 5/2025 consistent with fatty liver - reviewed with patient today. He continues famotidine daily which he feels has helped upper symptoms about 80%. He continues to have occasional heartburn and belching. Denies true regurgitation, nausea, dysphagia, or vomiting. He has abdominal burning and admits to having surgical opinion about a month ago in Gonzales with Dr Manneli who did not feel surgery was warranted and he was diagnosed with Diastasis recti. He continues humira every other week but admits he was switched to biosimilar Simlandi about 6 weeks ago and symptoms have remained at baseline. He is currently having soft and formed bowel movements that can alternate with diarrhea and most days he goes to the restroom 4-5 times a day. He remains on colestipol BID - but  is unsure if this is helping. He has done xifaxin in the past with temporary results. Denies fecal incontinence or nocturnal stooling. He can see small amount of bright red blood with wiping which he attributes to intermittent hemorrhoid flares - denies currently. Denies melena, acholic stools, or unexplained weight loss.

Patient was originally diagnosed with Ulcerative colitis around 2003 with Dr Rao but then diagnosis was changed to Crohn's around 2016. He was originally on various mesalamines long term but was switched to humira every other week around 2016/2017 which he has been on since. He had SBO with ileocecal resection in Baton Rouge with Dr Barfield 2/2023 with pathology that revealed a small neuroendocrine tumor and he has been following Dr Du Since this. He admits he is overdue for follow up with Dr Du who he is supposed to follow every 6 months. Last visit with Dr Du 3/2025 with CT imaging. Prior CT 11/2024 with thickened small bowel loops left upper quadrant suggestive of enteritis, focal small bowel intussusception likely transient. Stool studies and labs 1/2025, drug levels and MRI enterography 2/2025. He took short course of steroids 2/2025 which helped his chronic GI symptoms some, no steroids since. Denies recent abx or sick exposures. He is due for repeat Colonoscopy 10/2025. He has never had an EGD. Denies lung or kidney disease. He is on baby aspirin.

Troy Hebert is a 58 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last visit 08/20/2024. History of Crohn's disease originally diagnosed around 2008/2009. He was on oral mesalamine but switched to sulfasalazine years ago and has felt he did well on this since this time. Denies abdominal pain. He is currently having normal bowel pattern. He will take stool softener and on occasion he will do MiraLAX for constipation which works well for him. Denies diarrhea, overt GI bleeding, fever. He can have fecal urgency at times. Denies fecal incontinence, nocturnal stooling. History of oropharyngeal dysphagia (presumed to be from neck surgeries) and has done speech therapy in the past which helped. He has followed ENT but admits it has been a while since his last follow up and will be seeing them in the future for hearing issues. History of GERD which is overall under control with omeprazole daily and pepcid in the evening. He has been unable to taper this without rebound heartburn and regurgitation. He can have intermittent belching at times. Denies nausea, vomiting, or unexplained weight loss. Last EGD 2022. Colonoscopy 2020 - he is due for repeat. Denies alcohol use in years. Ultrasound, Fibroscan and MRI enterography 2024 - reviewed with patient today. Esophagram and MBSS 2022-2023. He h as Charcot Marie Tooth Syndrome and has required multiple orthopedic surgeries due to this. He had right foot procedure in May with Dr McKenna in May. He is currently in wheelchair but can also walk with walker. He is on baby aspirin, denies other blood thinners. He has mild CAD but has not restrictions from a cardiac standpoint (he follows Dr Elias at TRHS). Denies lung disease or kidney disease. He is on celebrex, norco PRN, and lyrica. Denies smoking - quit in 2015.

Samuel Martin is a 65 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Status-post colonoscopy, findings reviewed and discussed. TA x 1 and 7 year recall. He is taking 1 tablespoon of Metamucil daily. He has a bowel movement 4 times per day that are formed. This is his normal bowel pattern. He does report infrequent diarrhea with identifiable dietary triggers and this has been most of his life. He denies overt GI bleeding, constipation, and lower abdominal pain. He has never started dicyclomine. He remains on Pantoprazole 40mg once daily. He denies dysphagia, nausea, vomiting, and epigastric pain. He does note breakthrough GERD symptoms only if he eats spicy foods or roux. This resolves on its own. EGD 2019 with Dr. Winstead with suspected Barrett's esophagus, but esophageal biopsy was negative for intestinal metaplasia. He denies family history of esophageal cancer. He smokes cigars infrequently. He drinks alcohol infrequently. He denies unintentional weight loss. He denies family history of colon cancer.

Lindsey Prestenbach is a 32 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last visit with Colonoscopy - reviewed with patient today. Prior to this she has CBC, CMP, CRP and fecal which was normal. Shortly after colonoscopy she presented to urgent care due to increase diarrhea and fecal urgency and was given dicyclomine and loperamide. She is no longer requiring loperamide and continues dicyclomine daily (most days). Overall she is at least 70% better. She is currently having daily bowel movement or every other day bowel movements. She not had diarrhea in about a week. Stools have been soft and formed. Denies recent fecal urgency, recent overt GI bleeding. She has been having intermittent lower/pelvic pressure and RUQ abdominal pain. Recent GYN workup with pelvic ultrasound and is waiting on results - she sees Chris Rodrigue. Denies dysphagia, nausea, vomiting, GERD symptoms, or unexplained weight loss. Several family members with IBD, no first degree family members. Denies family history of colon cancer. History of anemia around 8 years ago (and around pregnancy/childbirth). No recent abx or recent travel. Denies frequent NSAID use or alcohol use. Denies smoking. History of IBS and remote history of nonspecific colitis with colonoscopy in 2015 (Pellegrin). She took 5 ASA x 1-2 years after this which she did well with and then discontinued and has not taken since. CBC and CRP 03/2022 normal. fecal calprotectin in July 2022 ok. She has never had an EGD. She still has her gallbladder and appendix.

Chester Vegas is a 82 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last visit 06/06/2025. He presents today with continued complaints of intermittent diarrhea and bloating. He has most recently started oral mesalamine 3 daily which he initially felt helped and then he lost response. Recent stool studies ordered with c-diff negative, stool culture negative, and fecal calprotectin never received (it appears fecal fat was run instead with total fat increase, neutral fat normal) - reviewed all with patient and wife. He has previously tried and failed colestipol and did not tolerate MiraLAX. Partial response to pepto and Imodium. He is currently having 3-4 bowel movements a day most days, on less common occasion he can have up to 4-5 bowel movements a day and can also on rare occasion go up to 2-3 days without a bowel movement. Stools can vary in consistency from loose and watery, semiformed and on less occasion soft and formed. He did not feel fiber helped in the past but admits to recently restarting this over the past couple of days and does feel like he has had some response this time. Denies overt GI bleeding, acholic stools, mucous in stool, fever. He has intermittent generalized abdominal cramping which could be worse postprandially and sometimes with or prior to defecation. Denies dysphagia, nausea, vomiting, GERD symptoms remain under control on pantoprazole. Weight is stable. He remains on plavix, ezetimibe, and aspirin. Denies NSAID Use. He continues to smoke 6-7 cigs/day. Denies alcohol use. CT 9/2024. Stool studies 11/2024 ok (other than fecal cal 135). CT and labs 9/2024. VCE and EGD 2019. Colonoscopy 2017. Due to his age and comorbidities, he would still like to avoid endoscopic workup if possible. Recent apptmt with Dr Vander and kidney function has declined more and Dr Vander has concerns that patient's bowel habits could be a contributing factor. He will have upcoming repeat labs to recheck this. He does not have his gallbladder.

56-year-old lady who I saw in consultation for Fatty liver.

She had blood tests done prior to starting on Wegovy 1 year ago which apparently revealed abnormal liver profile. The plan was to monitor the response of this to weight loss on the Wegovy but despite losing 80 pounds the liver profile is persistently abnormal. She does not know whether current results are better. No family history of liver disease. No history of alcohol excess, intravenous drug use or tattoos. No blood transfusions. No prior abnormal liver profile. Works as a process engineer. Is not on any other new medications. Takes fish oil, co-Q10, vitamin E, vitamin D, niacin 500 mg once a day and DIM. Does not have any history of hypertriglyceridemia. Not diabetic.

On omeprazole 40 mg nightly her heartburn was under good control. She reduced this to 20 mg nightly about 2 weeks ago. She does not have any heartburn at this time but was having it all through the day and night in the past. It is more often in the evening and night. Has never tried Pepcid. No nausea, vomiting or dysphagia. Has loss of appetite on the Wegovy. No abdominal pain.
Bowels move every other day. No blood in the stool or black stool. No family history of colon cancer.
6/2018 colonoscopy revealed 5 mm rectal polyp and 7 mm sigmoid polyp. Both were hyperplastic. Internal hemorrhoids.

5/20/2024 CMP was normal apart from AST 85 and ALT 161. TSH 1.305. Ferritin 111. CBC was normal. Vitamin D 35. Cholesterol 246. Triglycerides 108. Hepatitis B surface antigen and hepatitis C antibody were negative. ANA was negative.
8/22/2024 right upper quadrant ultrasound revealed changes consistent with cholecystectomy. Liver was of normal texture and echogenicity.
FibroScan did not reveal any evidence of liver fibrosis.

She did not get the blood work done that I had requested at the last visit. On the Pepcid 20 mg nightly she was having heartburn in the evening and at night. The symptoms improved when she resumed the omeprazole 20 mg after dinner. Denies any nausea, vomiting or dysphagia.

She has mild discomfort in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen which is constant. When she is busy she is not aware of it. Discomfort is localized to this area and there are no specific aggravating or relieving factors. No associated symptoms. The intensity is 1-2 out of 10.
Her bowels are regular without any recent change in bowel habit. No blood in the stool or black stool.

11/6/2024 liver profile was normal apart from AST 96 and ALT 152. Acute hepatitis profile was normal. Celiac profile was normal. Iron saturation 42%. Hemoglobin A1c 4.8. Actin antibody and M2 antibody were negative. Copper and ceruloplasmin were normal. Alpha-1 antitrypsin was normal.

11/11/2024 MRI abdomen with and without contrast was reported as no discrete lesions or adenopathy is observed. Delayed enhancing lesion in the medial spleen consistent with a small hemangioma. Hemorrhagic or proteinaceous cyst seen in the anterior left kidney. Nonspecific 0.5 cm cystic lesion in the head of the pancreas. Recommend 2-year follow-up MRI/MRCP to ensure stability.

She has gained 12 pounds since the last visit as she has not been able to get her Wegovy. On the omeprazole 20 mg every afternoon she does not have any heartburn. Denies any nausea, vomiting or dysphagia. The right upper quadrant abdominal pain has resolved

Bowels are regular without any recent change in bowel habit although eating unhealthy over Thanksgiving and Christmas she has constipation now. She has  increased her water and fiber intake to help regularize her bowel habit.
1/31/2025 CBC was normal. CMP was normal apart from creatinine 1.03, chloride 95, AST 77 and ALT 63.
2/26/2025 liver biopsy revealed hepatic parenchyma with features of resolving injury.
In December and January she stopped the Wegovy causing her to gain the 12 pounds. Since then she has lost 5 pounds which she attributes to resumption of the Wegovy. No nausea, vomiting or dysphagia.
She ran out of the omeprazole and since then she has been having heartburn around bedtime. She normally takes it around 930 pm. She does not usually eat supper.
The abdominal pain is infrequent. Bowels are regular without any recent change in bowel habit. No blood in the stool or black stool.
4/29/25 hepatic function panel was normal apart from ALT 67, normal 6-29.

She has gained 4 pounds since the last visit despite being on Wegovy which she attributes to stress eating from stress at work. The right upper quadrant abdominal discomfort has resolved. Denies any nausea, vomiting or dysphagia. She does not have any heartburn on the omeprazole 20 mg before dinner.
Bowels are regular without any recent change in bowel habit. No blood in the stool or black stool.

Reena Cruz  is a 35 year old   female  who is seen today for a follow-up visit on constipation and bloating. Pt's bloating has improved since her previous visit. They have stopped benefiber as they did not find any benefit with this. Pt is having a bowel movement every 2 days after utilizing enemas, and mom reports use of digital maneuvers/stimulation on occasion to help her defecate. She continues to be on Linzess 290mcg daily. Pt's parent states that her bowel movements that are soft or loose, and never hard. Pt is not utilizing a low FODMAP diet nor Mg supplements. She is not is having black tarry stools, blood in stools, nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain.

Reena Cruz  is a 36 year old   female  who is seen today for a follow-up visit on constipation and increased flatulence. Pt presents with her parents who is providing her history. Pt's mother states that pt has had increased symptoms since starting her menstrual cycle in September, which has resulted in increased irritation and overall discomfort. Pt's parents are concerned that her bowel habits are not regular enough and may be resulting increased irritability. Pt has been getting Linzess 290mcg daily, but pt's parents admit to improper administration as she is taking this with food and occasionally with dairy. Pt is still utilizing an enema every other day to help have bowel movements, but notes that there are time where no stool is evacuated with the enemas and only gas is released. Pt's stools are loose when she does have a bowel movement. She is not is having black tarry stools, blood in stools, nausea, vomiting, or unintentional weight loss. Of note, pt's parents were attempting to ween pt off her anti-epileptics, which resulted in a break through seizure last month. She is now working with a new neurologist and recently started on several new medications, which have also seemed to worsen her mood. Her diet has remained stable with limited sources of fiber. Pt had presented to the ER a few times where a CT A/P had been completed that was unremarkable. Lastly, pt's parents had inquired about possible colonoscopy or endoscopy.

Reena Cruz is a 36 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit on constipation, increased flatulence and GERD. Patient's mother D/C once has on April 1, which she has follow-up has significantly alleviated patient's abdominal bloating and flatulence. They are now utilizing prune juice daily along with a saline enema every 2 days with successful bowel movements that are easy to evacuate. She is no longer having excess flatulence or seeming to be in any significant abdominal discomfort. Patient is no longer utilizing stool softeners or MiraLAX. They are avoiding lactose and excess glucose intake. As for her long history of GERD, patient has been on Pepcid 40 mg once daily for several years with seemingly good control of patient's symptoms as there is no overt evidence that reflux is persisting. Typically, they are able to ""hear regurgitation"" when her reflux is poorly controlled, which has not been the case for several years. Therefore, they are interested in titrating off of Pepcid. Patient's parents deny signs of melena, hematochezia, vomiting, decreased appetite, or unintentional weight loss. Patient continues to have poorly controlled epilepsy and her last seizure was approximately 2 weeks ago, but they are working closely with patient's neurologist to optimize her medications.

Reena Cruz is a 36 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for constipation. Pt's mother states that approximately 2-3 weeks ago pt had a few days of increased irritability and poor bowel movements, which prompted them to bring pt to the ER for further evaluation. At the ER, pt was found to have fecal impaction on CT, and she was disimpacted using 2 saline enemas. Since discharge, pt has restarted Linzess 290mcg and docusate sodium 5mL daily along with saline enemas once every 2 days, which has kept her bowel habits well controlled. Pt has now been having one sufficient bowel movement every 2 days, and is not displaying irritability. She has not also not displayed any significant abdominal bloating or flatulence as she had in the past with the regimen. Pt's parents have been trying Her GERD remains well controlled on Pepcid 20mg once daily. Pt's mom denies flatulence, bloating, melena, hematochezia, abdominal pain, vomiting, poor appetite, or unintentional weight loss.

Able to speak with the Reyna's mother and father today, she is a 36-year-old noncommunicative patient that I have been following sometime with history of severe cerebral palsy and developmental delays. She is nonambulatory and has a BMI of 24, still having issues with constipation. She had been impacted on several occasions, we reviewed those previous, since her appointment in May she has had at least 1 other impaction. She has been given several different directions which I believe cause some confusion with how to utilize medical therapy to prevent this in the future. She has been given a prescription for lactulose 30 mL but told only to take it intermittently, she is not utilizing MiraLAX but will occasionally utilize docusate and Ex-Lax if symptoms develop. She is currently having 1-2 soft bowel movements a day without abdominal distention and her mother feels that she is quite comfortable at this time. She has been utilizing prune juice 8 ounces a day with successful management of her symptoms. We were able to review her overall situation, current medications and discussed strategies to prevent fecal impaction and constipation in the future.

Reena Cruz is a 37 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for constipation and decreased appetite. Patient again presents with her parents who are assisting in providing a history given patient is noncommunicative as a result of her severe cerebral palsy and developmental delays. Patient's parents report a decrease in p.o. intake over the last few months. Patient will appear hungry, and started eating a meal, but then after a few bites will purposely spit food back up without overt vomiting. However, on occasion she can complete a full meal. Patient has also turned down fluids, and will spit up water. Patient's mother states she is unsure if patient is in any pain though she can become agitated on occasion. Patient has lost about 10 pounds in the last 3 months. She remains on Pepcid 20 mg once daily, and was previously on 40 mg a day. Patient was evaluated by the dentist yesterday without any concerning findings. They have presented to Northeast Methodist ER last week due to her agitation and discomfort where a CT A/P, laboratory studies, UA, and checks x-ray were all unremarkable. Her constipation is intermittent and well-controlled dependent on her water intake. She remains on Linzess 290mcg once daily, docusate sodium 50mg/day, and prune juice as well as enemas prn. Pt's parents d/c miralax as it felt like it had caused more abdominal bloating, and also d/c lactulose as it was ""too aggressive"". Pt is currently having 1 BM every 2-3 days with small volumes of stool. They deny fevers, vomiting, or aspiration PNA. Pt is currently undergoing changes in her antiepileptics with her neurologist and had a breakthrough seizure 1 week ago

Reena Cruz is a 37 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for constipation and decreased appetite. Patient's parents state that patient began to experience severe abdominal discomfort including screaming and crying after use of Linzess and MiraLAX daily. Therefore, over the last 2 weeks they discontinued use of all prescription laxatives now only utilizing prune juice daily, increase water intake, exercise, and enemas every 2 to 3 days. On this regimen, patient is having 1 bowel movement every 2 to 3 days with soft stools of small to medium volume. She is no longer experiencing abdominal pain as she has decreased the screening and crying. Patient also continues to have significant flatus. Patient was unable to utilize pantoprazole as she was chewing the medication which is not recommended. That being said, patient is actually had improvement in her regurgitation and appetite. She is now refusing food less often and has been able to regain some weight. She does still occasionally spit food back out, but without overt vomiting. They continue to work with a neurologist and are titrating off of Lamictal. She has not had any breakthrough seizures since the last visit

Reena Cruz is a 37 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for constipation and decreased appetite. Patient's mother states that they restarted Linzess 290 mcg once daily approximately 2 weeks ago as patient did not tolerate lactulose. She is now doing well on Linzess and having bowel movements every 3 days with solid bowel movements utilizing enemas as needed. Patient also continues to take prune juice daily, but is not currently on MiraLAX. Patient's parents denies melena or hematochezia, and feel as though she is not in as much discomfort. They do utilize Gas-X as needed if they know her meals may result in worsening abdominal distention. In regards to her appetite, this appears to be back to baseline as she is eating 2 meals a day and tolerating a relatively normal diet. They deny any significant regurgitation or vomiting, and her weight has been stable. Patient has not having any fevers or significant choking episodes. She remains on famotidine 40 mg once at night and is not currently utilizing pantoprazole. Patient is also now off of Lamictal and remains only on Vimpat, and has not had any recent breakthrough seizures.

Reena Cruz is a 37 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for unintentional weight loss. Patient's parents state that they had brought patient to the ER for evaluation due to findings of significant unintentional weight loss down to 97 pounds. They completed laboratory testing that did have evidence of a UTI, but was otherwise unremarkable. Patient is able to tolerate p.o. intake, but occasionally will have forceful swallows, regurgitation, and liquids dribbling out her mouth, which could be indicative of difficulty swallowing though may also just be related to patient's refusal to eat. However, she also has periods of time where she is tolerating a completely normal diet and eating all meals without problem. Patient does remain on famotidine 40 mg a day as well. Her bowel habits are currently well-controlled utilizing increased water intake, exercise, and enemas as needed. Patient was very irritable on both Linzess, lactulose, and MiraLAX as she was exhibiting increased irritability, and thus they discontinued use. She is now having a soft and formed bowel movement every 2 to 4 days with the use of enemas. Patient has not had any recurrence of impactions since incorporating this regimen. They deny evidence of vomiting, melena, medic easier, or fevers. Patient did suffer a free seizure on 04/13 due to side effect of one of the antibiotics initially given for her UTI, but was previously stable and has not had a seizure since.

column1: Reena Cruz is a pleasant 38-year-old female with a past medical history of severe cerebral palsy and intellectual delay who is onverbal and presents for a follow-up on constipation and GERD. Therefore, it is reasonable to continue with pt's current course, but again cautioned her parents extensively to be vigilant for signs of fecal impactions given her history and also monitor her weight closely continuing with protein shakes daily. Patient's parents expressed understanding and agreed with plan.

Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Thank you APN Johnson for the opportunity to care for Ms. Cruz"

- Reglan 5 mg PRN does seem to help improve symptoms, but using very infrequently.

- Currently, weight has remained stable since last office visit, but she does wish she had an improved appetite, as she continues to find it difficult to eat enough to gain some healthy weight, maintain nutrition, and stay as hydrated as she would like.
- Only eating in the afternoon/evening. Due to lack of appetite, typically does not eat throughout the morning, and if she does it is only a small snack.
-- Today ate small yogurt, but is noting some mild epigastric discomfort/dyspepsia; confirms she did not take Reglan prior to eating the yogurt.

column1: Has had intermittent RUQ/epigastric abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting since early 2024, leading to diagnosis of gastroparesis April 2025 (GES 4-hour retention 43%.)
-Due to severity of symptoms, has lost significant weight since August 2024, leading to her last visit August 2025, where symptoms were largely preventing her from tolerating most p.o. intake.
-At that time was using Reglan 5 mg only sparingly, though it was acknowledged at her May 2025 visit that Reglan did help improve her symptoms.
Today, confirms that if she uses Reglan 5 mg prior to eating, she does not experience issues with abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting.
-Still only using Reglan around 1-2x/day, when eating  ""meals.""
-With this, weight has stabilized, but CC is persistent decreased appetite.
-Increase Reglan 5 mg to scheduled, 3 times daily.
--Take 1 tablet in the morning, monitoring for any improvement in appetite. Also to allow her to eat even something small without fear of developing gastroparesis symptoms.
--Continue dose with afternoon meal, and again in the evening scheduled.
--Recommend using a fourth dose as needed for any further snacks during the day.
-Aware of potential side effects, including TD, with Reglan, aware to stop the medication and contact clinic for any concerning signs or symptoms.
--Long-term plan continues to be reducing dose to as needed in the future once acute flare has resolved.
-Follow up with PCP to address low TSH (FT4 WNL.)
-Persistent chronic anemia, likely related to anemia of chronic disease, possibly exacerbated by folate deficiency.
-Ferritin elevated 625. Patient confirms she has not been on iron supplementation, oral/IV, for 6+ months.
--March 2025- ferritin 497. Sept 2018, initial liver serology workup, ferritin 216.
-Refer to hematology for further evaluation and management, particularly given her recent low white blood cell count.
Of note, previously seen in 2018 for elevated LFTs, workup with overall suspected NASH. Referred to Pinnacle.
-Referred back April 2022 for persistently elevated LFTs, on tacrolimus given transplant status.
--FibroScan CAP 251, kPa 7.6. Referred to MSTH hepatology.

-Expect her acute gastroparesis symptoms to be well-managed on Reglan, leading to improved nutrition and weight. At that time, when patient is stabilized, can readdress her liver status, and confirm she reestablishes with hepatology, if not still following.

Patient is a 57-year-old F referred by Dr. Vazquez who presents as a follow-up for MASLD. Patient was seen by Dr. Masters on 5/2021. Patient was seen on 3/2022 with stable symptoms. She was on various immunosuppresants and pending IVIG infusions. On her visit on 9/2022, she was doing well and remained on IVIG and various immunosuppressants. She remained on Dicyclomine twice a day. On her visit on 9/2023 she was doing well. She had labs with an intermittent spike in her LFTs but with subsequent normalization. She was seen on 9/17/2024 and reported that since her last visit she was started on Insulin due to dyspepsia which prompted PPI trial and HP breath test which was negative off PPI. She reports she was off Ozempic since 5/2024.

Currently she reports that she is currently on Afrezza for diabetes. She is currently being worked up from endocrinology for an autonomic dysfunction. She had a recent CT AP in 7/8/2025 as noted below. She is doing well on famotidine at night.  She denies nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, diarrhea, or constipation.
Available records reviewed and include the following:
LIVER PARENCHYMA WITH MODERATE MACROVESICULAR STEATOSIS AND MILD CHRONIC LOBULAR INFLAMMATION. FIBROSIS, ABSENT. IRON STAIN IS NEGATIVE.
Nuclear medicine gastric emptying study: 7/2024 mildly delayed emptying at the first hour, normalizes by 4 hours
MRI Liver: 11/2024: 2.0-2.2kPa mild hepatic steatosis with normal liver iron and elastography.

CT AP: 7/8/2025: No suspiscious hepatic lesions. Hx CCY. No biliary ductal dilation. Nonspecific mild circumferential wall thickening of the urinary bladder. 0.7cm pulmonary nodule in the RLL. Right adrenal lipid rich adenoma measuring 1.2cm.

column1: 1. MASLD - Patient has a history of MASLD with fibroscan and liver biopsy confirming macrovesicular steatosis with minimal fibrosis. Her labs have shown an elevated ALP with normal AST/ALT. We discussed the pathophysiology and natural history of fatty liver disease. We discussed the importance of weight loss and dietary changes to reduce fatty liver and even fibrosis. Repeat FibroScan study revealing improved fibrosis score along with normal CMP. Repeat Fibroscan 9/2023 was slightly improved. We discussed lifestyle modifications including low fat diet, particularly the Mediterranean diet, weight loss, alcohol cessation, black coffee 2-3 cups daily (although pt is getting worked up for autonomic dysfunction), and exercise as tolerated. Will reassess labs and calculate FIB4/NAFLD score to assess risk. Will repeat Fibroscan in 1 year since her MR Elastography in 11.2024 demonstrated mild hepatic steatosis without evidence of fibrosis.

2. GERD with esophagitis - The patient reports history of regurgitation previously placed on H2B at bedtime. She is currently taking Pepcid 40 mg p.o. at bedtime and sx are controlled at this time. Will continue.

3. Constipation: DDx. includes medication induced v. chronic idiopathic constipation v. IBS-C v. slow transit constipation v. pelvic floor dysfunction v. metabolic derangements v. lack on fluid/fiber intake etc. We discussed the pathophysiology and natural history of the various causes of constipation. Further diagnostic testing includes laboratory testing, imaging, and endoscopic evaluation. We discussed the various symptoms of constipation including infrequency, excessive straining, incomplete emptying, hard stools, bloating, use of digital evacuation etc. At this stage, will plan to optimize the patient's bowel regimen with MIraLAX 1-3x/day and Citrucel 1-2 tabs/day, titrated based on symptoms. Increase exercise as tolerated. I advised to maintain adequate hydration with at least 64 oz/day with exercise as tolerated. This usually occurs in accordance with her IVIG infusions. She takes Miralax and that relieves her constipation.

4. Delayed gastric emptying: NM GES: 7/2024 with delayed emptying at 1hr, but normal by 4hr. We discussed that this is not diagnostic of gastroparesis, but patient may have symptoms with these findings- difficult to clinically correlate but generally treated like gastroparesis. She reports a family history of GP and has dysautonomia with DM which can result in these findings.
Recommend lifestyle modifications- low fat diet, avoid alcohol consumption, and exercise 30 minutes per day, with a goal of 5x/weekly.
Lose weight with diet/exercise as discussed. Attempt 10% body weight loss over 6 months.*
Avoid herbal remedies, supplements, or medications other than those recommended by healthcare provider
Renew famotidine 40 mg TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH EVERYDAY AT BEDTIME
Drink at least 64oz of water daily

History of Present Illness: Patient presents with history of gastric ulcer and recent acid reflux. Reports experiencing acid reflux and esophageal burning approximately three weeks ago, which led to aspiration and subsequent diagnosis of asthma by pulmonologist. Patient has history of stomach problems from 20 years ago, including hiatal hernia and ulcer, previously diagnosed via endoscopy and treated with medication. Recent symptoms include reflux and esophageal burning. Has been taking pantoprazole for last month, which has provided some relief. Initially took medication daily, but has now reduced frequency to every other day. Patient expresses desire for another endoscopy to assess hiatal hernia, check for ulcers, evaluate acid reflux damage, and screen for bacteria. Reports testing negative for H. pylori. Patient underwent colonoscopy last year, which revealed polyps (unknown type or histology)  and no cancer. Quit smoking last year but admits to occasional social smoking. Patient mentions preference for being asleep during endoscopy procedure due to sensitivity and asthma concerns.

Vanessa Pascual is a 41 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit to establish care since moving to TX from Florida this past summer.

She states that she has a hx of GERD and a hiatal hernia for which she underwent a fundoplication in Nov 2023. She had an EGD in May 2025 with Bravo and was told that everything was normal. She was advised to manage anxiety, so she was started on SSRI in June 2025 with significant relief to her GI sx. She also sees a therapist.

Patient states that she developed abdominal pain last August for which she was seen and evaluated by OBGYN and Urology then finally had a CT scan that showed uncomplicated diverticulitis for which she was treated with abx with relief to her sx. She underwent colonoscopy in May 2025 and was advised 7 year surveillance due to personal hx of colon polyps. Has had 3-4 colonoscopies in her lifetime and had her first one in her 20s due to hematochezia. She had been overall doing well until 2-3 weeks ago when she started to experience left sided and bilateral lower abdominal cramping. States sx are intermittent and occur randomly, not related to food intake. States sx are mild but overall annoying. Used to be on Dicyclomine per GI in Florida with relief. However, she experienced 3 episodes of diarrhea about 3 days ago. Stools have become more formed but still more loose than her baseline. Stools currently BSS 5-6 and her baseline is 4. Both daughters have been sick recently. cramping resolves with Tylenol but can last a couple of hours when she does not take Tylenol. She is focusing on oral hydration and taking metamucil five capsules per day. This regimen is keeping her bowel movements regular otherwise she tends to suffer from constipation, averaging one bowel movement every 2 days with straining.
Denies unintentional weight loss, nausea, vomiting or blood in stool. Has intermittent dysphagia ever since her fundoplication. Had celiac testing that was negative in the past.
Mom had breast cancer that metastasized to the colon. Denies family history of primary colon cancer, esophageal, gastric, or pancreatic cancer.
New Exercise Cardio 2-3 times a week.
No history of Inflammatory bowel disease, Liver disease

column1: Elevated LFTs: Differential diagnosis of the patient's abnormal liver function testing includes gallstones, NAFLD, NASH, viral hepatitis, autoimmune hepatitis, thyroid disease, hemochromatosis, Wilson's Disease, Alpha-1 Anti trypsin disease, Drug-Induced Liver Injury, or others. Suspect due to cholelithiasis and hepatic steatosis. Will request copy of most recent labs from general surgeon (post surgery) for review. If still elevated, will consider repeat HFP vs hepatic workup. Treat hepatic steatosis as below.

Hepatic steatosis: We discussed the pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment of fatty liver disease. Risk factors include elevated BMI, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes but also highlighting that it is a diagnosis of exclusion. We discussed the spectrum of fatty liver and potential progression to cirrhosis as well as the potential complications of cirrhosis, but provided reassurance that this change occurs over time. I recommended abstinence from alcohol, and to pursue diet, exercise, and weight loss with a goal to lose at least 7-10% of body weight to help reverse steatosis and early fibrotic changes.

Nausea: Broad DDx. overall, that from a GI standpoint would include, but is not limited to, GERD v. peptic ulcer disease v. obstructive etiology v. gastroparesis v. constipation v. IBS v. IBD v. cannabis hyperemesis syndrome v. cyclical vomiting syndrome, less likely malignancy or ischemic processes. Certainly, extra-gastrointestinal etiologies are a consideration as well, especially if basic GI workup is unrevealing. OTC Prilosec ineffective. Start pantoprazole 40 mg before dinner as below. Avoid NSAIDs. We discussed a GERD diet in detail, patient should avoid trigger foods, avoid late meals, and elevate the head of the bed. Can consider EGD for further evaluation if symptoms worsen/fail to improve.
Recommend lifestyle modifications- low fat diet, avoid alcohol consumption, and exercise 30 minutes per day, with a goal of 5x/weekly.

Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil, ibuprofen, Aleve, Naproxen, etc.)
pantoprazole 40 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth once a day 30 min before dinner
Medication side effects, complications, risks, benefits, alternatives, follow-up and compliance discussed with the patient.
Call office with any questions or concerns.
My office will obtain records from referring physician Copy of recent HFP from general surgeon's office

Connie Young is a 78-year-old woman with a PMH HLD, mood disorder, and PMR and long term prednisone who presents for diarrhea.

She reports the onset of copious watery diarrhea over the past month. She is having 3-4 BM daily and 2-3 at night. Strikes with signficant urgency and high volume. No overt GIB but she has had FOBT testing since the onset of her symptoms and three separate tests came back positive. She notes a weight loss of 7 pounds over this time period as well. She's not certain that any particular type of food triggers her symptoms. SHe has some abdominal pain but no bloating. No dysphagia or dyspepsia. SHe's had some relief with imodium 4mg in the morning. No benefit from lomotil.

This occurs in the context of a prednisone taper. SHe's been on prednisone nearly continuously for several decades for her PMR. Currently taking 2mg daily and notes that even taking 2mg a day makes a big difference for her joint pain. She has had issues with diarrhea previously when her prednisone was tapered.
Her last colonoscopy was in 2003 and was reportedly normal. She rports doing ColoGuard since that time with her last negative cologuard in 2022.
Describes some oropharyngeal dysphagia which she attributes to chronically having a dry mouth.

column1: Significant watery diarrhea onset with prednisone wean. She has experienced similar symptoms when her prednisone was weaned in the past. No abdominal bain. Concern for an unmasked inflammatory diarrhea (eg microscopic colitis, IBD) vs a manifestation of adrenal insufficiency. Acute infectious diarrhea less likely given duration, but parasitosis and celiac dz plausible.
- Titrate imodium at 4mg up to four times a day. Counseled her to titrate this slowly
- Metmaucil pills (patient does not like powder or gummies) for stool consistency
- If symptoms persistent/severe despite these changes, can introduce budesonide pending colonoscopy
- Colonosocpy to assess for microscopic colitis and IBD; she should take prednisone 10mg daily for two days prior and the day of her procedure given the possibility of adrenal insufficency

Risks and benefits statement: The procedure and its preparation, benefits, alternatives, and limitations were explained to the patient or legal guardian. The risks and potential complications including but not limited to perforation, bleeding, infection, missed lesion, aspiration and other complications of sedation were reviewed. The patient or legal guardian verbalized understanding and wishes to proceed.

- Your main issues are constipation, bloating, abdominal pain, and some bleeding. We discussed that these symptoms are significantly influenced by your hormonal cycle, but we will focus on managing the GI aspects.

- We will proceed with a colonoscopy to check for the cause of bleeding, such as hemorrhoids, and to ensure the colon is healthy. At the same time, we will perform an upper endoscopy (EGD) to look at your esophagus and stomach for the cause of the lump-in-throat sensation.
- You must stop taking your acid reflux pill (Prilosec or similar) for at least two weeks before the procedures. You can use Tums or Gaviscon Extra Strength for heartburn if needed.

- We will stop the Linzess. Instead, you will start taking Miralax. Mix two tablespoons in a water bottle each morning and sip it throughout the day. This dose can be adjusted down if your stools become too loose. The goal is to keep your stools soft without causing diarrhea.
- I recommend trying a gluten-free and dairy-free diet to see if it helps with your bloating and pain.
- We also discussed a specific sitting posture for having a bowel movement.

column1: Stuart Ware is a 44 year old  male patient who is seen at the request of Nickolas Hadley for a consultation/initial visit. This is a patient here to see me for evaluation of hematochezia. The bleeding has been occurring for a prolonged period, estimated to be at least two years. The bleeding is described as bright red blood that turns the toilet water red, and is also admixed within the stool. The appearance can be both bright red and dark red, with some clots. The onset of symptoms is recalled to be shortly after a major surgery in 2020 for a brain aneurysm, which involved a trans-femoral approach through the groin. During that period, they were on multiple medications, including corticosteroids, which have since been discontinued for years.

The patient reports associated changes in bowel habits for a similar duration. There is an increased frequency of bowel movements, occurring multiple times per day with small volumes. Stool consistency varies from soft and loose to pebble-like, but is not described as frank diarrhea. Mucus is also present in the stool. They report a sensation of incomplete evacuation and straining, feeling as though there is a blockage. The stool form is sometimes described as thin or pencil-like. There are no upper GI symptoms such as heartburn, reflux, nausea, vomiting, or dysphagia. There is no reported abdominal pain.

The past medical history is significant for psoriasis, which predates the gastrointestinal symptoms, without associated arthritis. There is a history of a brain aneurysm which was treated surgically in 2020. There is no history of ulcers in the mouth, no rashes other than the known psoriasis, and no painful vision or eye inflammation. There are no known complications from prior procedures or anesthesia.

Social history is negative for smoking, intravenous drug use, or nasal drug use. Alcohol and marijuana use were not discussed. There is a negative family history for colon cancer or colon polyps. There is no family history of other gastrointestinal issues.

There has been some intentional weight loss since January of this year due to dietary changes, described as ""eating cleaner"" with fewer processed foods. This change was made for their daughter's health, which is not gastrointestinal in nature. There has been no unintentional weight loss.

column1: 1. Hematochezia and change in bowel habits: The primary concern is the chronic hematochezia, described as bright red blood per rectum, associated with mucus, increased stool frequency, and a change in stool caliber to being pencil-like at times. The differential diagnosis is broad. Given the bright red nature of the blood, this is most likely from a lower GI source. Common causes include internal hemorrhoids, which are often painless, and anal fissures, though fissures are typically painful. Given the change in bowel habits, sensation of blockage, and mucus, more significant pathology such as colonic polyps, diverticulosis, or a neoplasm must be ruled out. Additionally, given the history of psoriasis, an associated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) such as ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease is a consideration, as autoimmune conditions can cluster. Mucus in the stool is often a marker of inflammation. The current symptoms warrant a direct visualization of the colon.
Given ongoing clinical issues suspect  colon or distal small bowel source. Will start with colonoscopy

- A colonoscopy is planned to investigate the etiology of the hematochezia and change in bowel habits. We will look for inflammation, ulceration, polyps, diverticulosis, hemorrhoids, and any other abnormalities. Biopsies will be taken of any abnormal-appearing tissue, and any polyps found will be removed.

- The risks and benefits, preparation, and procedural details were discussed and any questions were answered. Risks discussed include a less than 1% risk of perforation, bleeding, and infection. It was explained that the procedure would be performed with deep sedation using propofol, administered by an anesthesia provider. The need for a driver to and from the procedure was also explained.
- Follow-up will be scheduled after the procedure to discuss the findings and any further management.

This is a follow-up visit for a 56-year-old male to discuss the results of a recent colectomy. The procedure was performed due to a history of mild and well-controlled ulcerative colitis. He tolerated the procedure well, with no issues post-operatively, and continues to be asymptomatic. The colectomy involved removal of a polyp in the sigmoid colon. Random biopsies were also taken throughout the colon. He has a known history of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and undergoes surveillance for an increased risk of colon cancer. He reports no current gastrointestinal complaints. He is also being monitored for PSC with regular liver scans and blood work.

- Colonoscopy with biopsy: A polyp in the sigmoid colon was removed. Biopsy results showed a hyperplastic polyp, which is benign. Random biopsies from other areas of the colon were negative for colitis.

- Labs from 07/09/2025: ALT, AST, and alkaline phosphatase were normal. CA 19-9 was slightly elevated at 41, which is consistent with prior results. Alpha-fetoprotein was 6.1. Hemoglobin was normal. Platelet count was 182.
- Abdominal Ultrasound with Dopplers from 07/09/2025: Performed by Dr. McFadden. No MRI has been performed this year. The last abdominal MRI was in December of the previous year.
- CT Chest: Performed by Dr. Dial for evaluation of a lung nodule seen on a chest x-ray, which was done for a cough. The nodule has reportedly been present since his teenage years.

8/18/2025 This is a telehealth appointment conducted from my office at 11920 Astoria Blvd Suite 440 Houston, TX 77089 using audio connection only. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow up visit. He followed up with transplant team in 07/2025 and underwent labs and liver ultrasound at that time. He was told that his PSC is relatively stable and to follow up in 6 months. He remains on mesalamine for his UC with good control of his GI symptoms. He denies any ongoing abdominal pain, change in bowel movement, rectal bleeding. He is due for colonoscopy for colorectal cancer surveillance, which I will order today. He is not due for EGD, given that he had EGD in 06/2024 and overall feels stable on pantoprazole 40mg QD. Discussed risks and benefits of procedure with patient.

4/16/2025 He is here for routine follow-up after almost a year. In the meantime he has been following with Methodist transplant hepatology regarding PSC. We reviewed his most recent MRI which was done in December with stable fibrotic changes and no focal suspicious liver lesion. No dominant stricture or extrahepatic biliary dilation noted. Labs are significant for slightly elevated CA 19-9 at 55. Patient denies any recent UC symptoms. Specifically no diarrhea, rectal bleeding, or abdominal pain. He was very recently diagnosed with diabetes and A1c of 6.7. He was started on metformin after insurance denied Ozempic and reports that stools are little softer on metformin. Encouraged diet and exercise implementation and could consider stool testing if he develops diarrhea in the future. Otherwise he is due for surveillance colonoscopy in September.

5/14/2024 He is here for routine follow-up along with his wife. Recently reports worsening GERD symptoms and new onset globus sensation. He saw an ENT doctor who ordered barium video esophagram. Results reviewed with patient including moderate gastroesophageal reflux and no stricture. He has been taking Alka-Seltzer with partial symptomatic response. He is also on Pepcid which he takes in combination with Allegra for his allergies. No prior PPI use. He has gained about 20 pounds since last year due to dietary indiscretion and decreased physical activity. He is going to physical therapy due to left hip pain and partial labrum tear. Discussed recommendations for weight loss and dietary modifications. Recommend repeat EGD given worsening symptoms. We did discuss the possibility of starting daily PPI however he would like to wait until after the procedure to start a new medication if necessary. UC symptoms are well-controlled. Continue mesalamine 2.4 g a day. He also had a recent MRI with his hepatologist in the Medical Center which we will request for records.

1/29/24 This is a telehealth appointment conducted from my office at 11920 Astoria Blvd Suite 440 Houston, TX 77089 using audio connection only. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow up visit. Patient reports feeling well today. He reports few episodes of intermittent diarrhea with associated rectal bleeding, which he attributes to poor diet. He also reports intermittent cramping in R side of abdomen. Denies fever, nausea, vomiting. Tolerating regular diet. He saw Dr. McFadden in 12/23 for his PSC and has surveillance MRI scheduled for 03/24. He plans to consult with new PCP through the VA in 04/24. He remains on ursodiol 250mg BID and mesalamine 1.2g 2 tablets daily. He had labs with Dr. McFadden in 12/23, which he reports are stable. We will request those today. Follow up in 3 months.

10/6/2023 Patient is here for procedure follow up. Colonoscopy in 09/23 with hyperplastic polyp, small internal hemorrhoids, biopsies negative for colitis and dysplasia. Recall colonoscopy in 2 years. Today, patient reports feeling well. He denies abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, visible GI bleeding. He has 1-2 formed BMs daily. He remains on mesalamine 1 tablet daily. He is working on scheduling follow up with Dr. McFadden over next couple of months. He is due for surveillance labs, which I will order today. Follow up in 3 months.

8/30/2023 Patient is here for follow up. Today, patient reports feeling well. Reports intermittent dull RUQ pain after eating certain foods. Denies nausea, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea, black or bloody stools. He remains on mesalamine BID. He followed up with Dr. McFadden in 06/23 and was told that his PSC was stable. He had labs and MRI at that time. He is due for a surveillance colonoscopy, which will be ordered today. Discussed risks and benefits of procedures with patient.

03/08/2023  Patient is here for routine follow up. He followed up with Dr. McFadden, hepatologist @ Methodist-TMC 1 month ago, who ordered repeat blood work and imaging. Patient was told that PSC is stable. No acute complaints today. Denies changes in BMs Had one episode of rectal bleeding with painful BM. Started metamucil last month, which has helped BMs become more regular. No additional rectal bleeding or painful BMs since starting metamucil. Denies abdominal pain, N/V, change in appetite. Patient due for next colonoscopy in 09/23.

12/08/2022 Since last visit he was sent to liver transplant department at UT who he was previously following up given concerns for progression of her primary sclerosing cholangitis on MRI done in July 2022 with either fibrosis versus cholangiocarcinoma. He was seen by the transplant hepatologist however due to some insurance issues he was referred to Methodist transplant center. Patient apparently had labs as well as an ultrasound with Dopplers done and has a follow-up back with them in few weeks. He denies any new concerns. Denies any abdominal pain nausea vomiting jaundice or diarrhea. He remains on ursodiol as well as LDL the for ulcerative colitis in remission.

09/01/2022 He is here for follow-up. No new complaints. He underwent upper endoscopy as part of preoperative evaluation for possible bariatric gastric sleeve procedure. Upper endoscopy was within normal limits without any evidence of varices or portal gastropathy. Gastric biopsies negative for H. pylori. He had a routine labs done that were within normal limits particularly normal liver function panel as well as normal CA 19â€“9. He had an MRI done as part of annual surveillance given primary sclerosing cholangitis that does show multifocal intrahepatic biliary ductal dilation of the right hepatic lobe consistent with the known diagnosis of PSC. Multifocal areas of T1 hypointense signal, T2 hyperintense signal enhancement on delayed postcontrast images noted, radiologist noted that even though the pattern is similar to prior MRI in April 2021 cholangiocarcinoma was favored given abnormal signal on T2 sequence. Given this finding I have recommended that he follow-up back with the transplant clinic for multidisciplinary review of his scans and further management. I recommended that he hold off on bariatric surgery for the time being until cleared by transplant clinic. As per ulcerative colitis symptoms are under control with the Lialda. He will be coming up due for a surveillance colonoscopy next year.

07/28/2022 Patient is here to discuss the possibility of bariatric surgery. Consideration for weight loss surgery was initially discussed with him by his cardiologist given BMI of 40 and associated risk for cardiovascular disease. He does have a history of ulcerative colitis which is well controlled with Lialda as well as PSC. He is planning to do a repeat MRI for PSA surveillance tomorrow. No recent EGD and I have recommended this to help rule out any varices in the esophagus or stomach. He has a history of reflux however this is quite mild recently and controlled with H2 blocker only as needed. Per patient, he has been seeing Dr. Trahan and gastric sleeve has been preferentially recommended to him over gastric bypass so as to preserve endoscopic access to bile ducts if needed. No absolute contraindication for the surgery in his case. We will review repeat imaging and EGD findings prior to giving final recommendations to patient/surgeon.

04/12/2022 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using bidirectional synchronous video communication tool. Has inquired about bariatric surgery however I strongly recommended lifestyle modifications initially given his comorbidities. UC symptoms are well controlled on Lialda 2 tablets daily. He reports he had a CT scan a few months ago when he went to Methodist Hospital with infection of unclear origin- I will try to get these records. He is due for labs including tumor markersâ€“CA 19-9 and MRI. Up-to-date on screening colonoscopy. Next one will be due in 2023. I provided refills for his GI medications. He is also requesting a short-term refill of Flomax which he takes for BPH since he has been unable to obtain this from PCP.

9/29/2021 This is a procedure follow up after recent colonoscopy. Discussed procedure findings in detail including small 5 mm rectal polyp which was hyperplastic on pathology. Pathology showed colonic eosinophilia more on the right side without dysplasia. Ulcerative colitis symptoms have been well controlled with Lialda 2 tablets daily and I recommend that he continue current dosage. He is having about 2 BM per day without bleeding or abdominal pain.  He will follow-up in 6 months or sooner if he has any worsening symptoms. From a PSC standpoint, patient was given an order for CA 19-9 labs at his last visit however has misplaced this and I posted to the portal again for him. We will call patient with these results once available. Total time spent was 20 minutes.

9/1/21 Is here for routine follow-up. He had recent labs done with his PCP which were all within normal limits. He will need a CA 19â€“9. Liver function tests were normal. Last MRI was in April 2021 that showed stable irregularity of the intrahepatic biliary tree, normal caliber common bile duct, chronic periductal fibrosis and inflammation with partial right hepatic atrophy. She has gained 20 pounds due to dietary indiscretion, states that has been stress eating and has recently quit his job. Recommended diet, lifestyle changes. He is due for screening colonoscopy given history of ulcerative colitis. Symptoms are stable on Lialda.

04/05/2021 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office using bidirectional synchronous video communication tool. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow-up visit. Most recent liver function tests from a month ago were within normal limits. He underwent a HIDA scan for intermittent right upper quadrant pain which was within normal limits with ejection fraction of 50% after a fatty meal. As such cholecystectomy was not recommended unless symptoms become severe. He will need a surveillance MRI with regards to PSC. He remains on Lialda for ulcerative colitis which appears to be in remission.

10/01/2020 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office using bidirectional synchronous video communication tool. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow-up visit. We discussed colonoscopy results which were overall normal without any evidence of active colitis. 2 polyps were noted which were removed and were noted to be hyperplastic. He denies any diarrhea or rectal bleeding. We have agreed to continue Lialda, folic acid supplementation as well as probiotic daily. As per PSC, his most recent liver enzymes have been stable. We discussed the ERCP findings from June 2020. Common biliary stent was removed. He does have mild intermittent right upper quadrant pain more so when he eats a fatty meal. Cholangiogram did show good filling of gallbladder without any filling defects. I did discuss possibility of a calculus cholecystitis or biliary dyskinesia. I recommend a nuclear medicine HIDA scan and if positive may consider referral to transplant hepatic surgeon for elective cholecystectomy. Given COVID pandemic and since symptoms are mild if agreed to hold off on the referral list here. We will follow-up back with him in 4 months with repeat labs. Given that he had an ERCP in June he decided to postpone the MRI imaging to next year.

07/02/2020 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office using bidirectional synchronous video communication tool. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow-up visit. He underwent repeat ERCP a month ago with removal of stent. Common bile duct measures 6 to 7 mm. Intrahepatics were narrow particularly on the right side which did not feel much. Balloon sweep with small amount of sludge no stones. Gallbladder did not fill. Patient notes improvement in right upper quadrant pain. No fever. His liver function tests were done recently which were within normal limits. Therefore I have asked him to hold off and not go back on ursodiol for the time being. He remains on Lialda 2.4 g with good control of ulcerative colitis symptoms. He is due for colonoscopy which will be scheduled later once the current COVID surge numbers have improved. His CA 19â€“9 level has come down a little bit but remains persistently elevated over the last 3 to 4years. No mass lesions noted on recent imaging. We will repeat another MRI with liver mass protocol prior to the end of the year and moving forward I recommended that we will be doing this every 6 months to rule out cholangiocarcinoma. He did reestablish with liver transplant department and I have recommended to keep in touch with them at least every 6 months if possible. In addition he has gained about 30 pounds primarily due to COVID and not exercising. I have strongly recommended diet exercise regimen to decrease risk of fatty liver disease.

04/20/2020 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using bidirectional synchronous video communication tool. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow-up after recent procedure. Patient underwent elective ERCP given history of primary sclerosing cholangitis, right upper quadrant pain and slight elevated tumor markers. He was noted to have diffuse multifocal strictures throughout the extrinsic common bile duct right intrahepatic duct did not feel much which corresponds to draw prominent right liver lobe on MRI, left intrahepatics filled but were very probably, brushings were taken and showed reactive ductal epithelial cells but no malignant cells. A 10 French 9 cm plastic stent was left in place. Cholangioscopy was not done due to very narrow size of the common bile duct. Patient did have mild fever after the procedure and a follow-up CT was done after patient was admitted and did not show any hepatic abscess. He completed treatment with antibiotics. We have discussed long-term treatment options for primary sclerosing cholangitis, discussed removal of the stent with the possibility of worsening liver function tests. I recommended that he reconnect with the liver transplant center. He will continue on the ursodiol for the time being. We will bring him back in another 2 months to consider removal of the stent. IgG subclass 4 was sent and was not elevated. He notes improvement in right upper quadrant pain and no fever or chills at this time. Risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed.

01/29/2020 He is here to follow-up after Recent work-up. Labs show resolution in liver function tests, CA 19â€“9 remains elevated at 44. GFR is 44. He had a surveillance MRI that showed a normal gallbladder but the multifocal intrahepatic bile duct narrowing with intrahepatic biliary dilation with the dominant right lobe compatible with primary sclerosing cholangitis. A focal stricture of the common hepatic duct was noted similar to previous MRI. Also noted was a questionable intraluminal filling defect in the common bile duct which was nonocclusive could be a stone sludge or mass lesion. Given these findings I have recommended that we proceed with ERCP with the possible cholangioscopy, biopsies brushings and possible stent placement. He has atypical chest discomfort and neck pain and therefore I recommended that he see a cardiologist first and get a clearance to proceed. Is also having some numbness in the left cheek for few weeks and plans to see a neurologist.

12/05/2019 Is here to follow-up after 6 months. Continues to have intermittent right upper quadrant pain. He had recent labs done in November 2019 which were pertinent for elevated ALT of 214. He was sick with upper respiratory tract infection was on antibiotics and steroids during that time. He also drinks about ounce and a half of hard liquor every day. I recommended to abstain from all alcohol use. He will repeat liver function tests and add CA 19â€“9 which is always been slightly elevated in his case. Is also due for MRCP given primary sclerosing cholangitis. He will be due for colonoscopy next year. Labs from his PCP included ESr and CRP which were normal.

5/16/2019 Since last visit he had consultation with UT hepatology dept; recommended current managment; Urso only if LFTs go up; recent labs show normal LFTs. MRCP with PSC changes; no mass. LDL sligly high; recommended diet/exercise.

1/25/2019 He is here for followup of ulcerative colitis as well as primary sclerosing cholangitis. MRI done Novoste of 2018 at Clear Lake regional showed changes of primary sclerosing cholangitis. Multifocal narrowing of the biliary tree and common hepatic duct was noted. CA 19-9 was 34 which has been the same for the last 6 years. Show normal liver function tests. However he is starting to notice right upper quadrant pain 3/10 dull achy occasional burning sensation without any fever or chills. We have discussed long-term treatment options With regards to PSC. We have discussed continue monitoring with labs versus ERCP with brushings of the stricture as well as stenting. Long term options with any worsening of his liver function including liver transplant was discussed and I did encourage him to get a second opinion from a liver transplant center. If he does start having any fever or chills are jaundice then advised him to call us back at which time an ERCP will be scheduled.

8/6/2018 He is here to discuss workup for ulcerative colitis and primary sclerosing cholangitis. He had a colonoscopy in June shows that his colitis is in remission. Biopsies did not show any evidence of active inflammation. Hyperplastic polyps were removed. He brought in labs from his PCP showed that his lipid panel is abnormal and his liver functions are completely normal. With regards to his PSC he had surveillance MRCP that showed focal narrowing of common hepatic duct approximately 15 mm above the cystic duct insertion. Common duct below this was normal at 6 mm. Right and left intrahepatic ducts show multifocal narrowing with irregular dilation notably in the right lobe of liver consistent with PSC. He does have occasional right upper quadrant discomfort but denies any fever or chills. No history of jaundice.

Bala Chavali is a 74 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit to discuss chest discomfort. At the last consultation, there was a concern that this discomfort was related to reflux. A medication adjustment was made, adding famotidine at night to the existing morning dose of omeprazole. Bala reports this regimen worked well and the chest discomfort resolved. Two weeks ago, she finished the omeprazole prescription and decided to discontinue it to see if symptoms would recur. So far, the symptoms have not returned, and she is doing well. Bala continues to take famotidine 40 mg at night.

Bala notes a significant change in dietary tolerance, stating that even mildly spicy food now causes symptoms, which manifest immediately as a throat sensation. This has been an ongoing issue for many years. They expressed concern about whether this dietary restriction will be permanent. It was explained that it is common for the digestive system to become less tolerant of certain foods over time and this may be a permanent change for them. Bala also inquired about the long-term need for medication. It was discussed that while they may be able to manage without omeprazole for a period, it is possible that symptoms may flare up in the future, requiring further treatment. A potential future strategy discussed was increasing famotidine to twice daily if a flare-up occurs, before reintroducing omeprazole. For now, since symptoms are controlled on famotidine 40 mg nightly, the plan is to continue this and hold off on the omeprazole.

Bala also reports ongoing issues with constipation. This is managed with a high-fiber diet, including taking Benefiber two to three times daily and eating an orange or clementine at night. These measures are effective. She reports that Miralax was not helpful and is no longer being used.

Bala is planning a trip to India in December for two and a half weeks. She is concerned about a potential flare-up of reflux symptoms, as a similar trip last year triggered severe gas pains that resulted in a hospital visit. To prevent a recurrence, a new prescription for omeprazole will be provided to have on hand for the trip.

This is a follow-up visit for Joyce, whom I last saw in March 2025 for severe constipation. At that time, her symptoms were thought to be related to sigmoid colon narrowing secondary to diverticulosis. She continues to experience constipation. She has been prescribed stool softeners and lactulose, which she is using. She titrates the lactulose dose based on her symptoms, currently taking one ounce (30 ml) in the morning and one ounce at night. She reports that some days she is in the bathroom for a significant portion of the morning, while on other days, like today, she has not had a bowel movement, highlighting the unpredictable nature of her symptoms. She notes that a few days ago, she went two days without a bowel movement and then had significant difficulty initiating one.

There is a significant history of an admission in January of this year for what was effectively an obstruction. She presented to the emergency room after passing out on the toilet, secondary to nausea and other symptoms. Imaging at that time confirmed her colon was completely full of stool. She was admitted to the hospital for three days and required a rectal tube for decompression and disimpaction. This experience has made her consider more definitive treatment options. Her anatomy, specifically severe narrowing in the sigmoid colon from diverticulosis, is the underlying cause of her chronic and unpredictable bowel habits.
- Colonoscopy from 05/2022 revealed severe narrowing in the sigmoid colon secondary to diverticular disease.

3/4/2025 Joyce is an 83-year-old female here for follow-up after being admitted to MHPL hospital for hypovolemic shock. She was noted to have extensive stool on CT and diverticulosis with luminal narrowing in the left colon, likely explaining severe constipation. She reports that her bowel movements have been inconsistent, with frequent bowel movements for a couple of days followed by a day without any bowel movement. She became allergic to Senna and Docusate, which she was taking for constipation, with hives on her toe within 30 minutes of taking the medication. This was the first time she was taking these medications. She has lost 12 pounds since the hospitalization but denies loss of appetite. She typically has a smoothie for breakfast and peanut butter.
- CT scan showed extensive stool and diverticulosis with luminal narrowing in the left colon

2/7/2025 She is here for hospital follow-up after recent admission for abdominal pain, vomiting, and syncopal event at home. She was admitted to Memorial Hermann Pearland for hypovolemic shock and gastroenterology was consulted for possible partial bowel obstruction versus ileus. From a GI standpoint she gradually improved and was discharged home on a soft diet. She did not require NG tube compression. CT findings included dilated stomach, small bowel, and colonic loops with thickening of the gastric antrum and a severe ileus/enteritis and early changes of shock bowel. She also has diverticulosis without diverticulitis. She required vasopressor support temporarily. Denies rectal bleeding or hematemesis. Blood pressure has been low normal since discharge per patient. She has a f/u with her cardiologist next week. Review of CT during office visit today shows extensive stool throughout colon and prior colonoscopy showed diverticulosis with luminal narrowing in the left colon. She is feeling okay other than mild bloating after meals.  Discussed with patient that her symptoms may be related to severe constipation and suggested a more regular bowel regimen. Consider repeat EGD/colonoscopy if symptoms worsen.

5/31/2022 This is a follow-up after recent EGD and colonoscopy. Upper endoscopy. Mild gastritis negative for H. pylori. She remains on omeprazole 40 mg once a day. She has remote history of gastric ulcers but given relatively negative upper endoscopy recommend to cut down the omeprazole to 20 mg. Colonoscopy without any evidence of polyps but does have sigmoid diverticulosis with luminal narrowing but able to pass a pediatric scope across all the way to the cecum. Grade 2 internal hemorrhoids noted. High-fiber diet and supplementation was recommended. If she does have recurrent attacks of diverticulitis then I would suggest a colorectal surgery evaluation. She is not interested in surgical referral at this time.

04/26/2022 This is a 80-year-old female with past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, history of ischemic colitis about 15 years ago recently was admitted to Memorial Hermann Pearland hospital 2 weeks ago with complaints of rectal bleeding as well as abdominal cramps that started 1 day prior to presentation. In the ER she was noted to have leukocytosis with white blood cell count of 19.1 lactic acidosis of 2.7, hemoglobin 11.3. CT scan showed mild to moderate diffuse left and proximal to mid sigmoid colitis and severe sigmoid and mild right colonic diverticulosis. Her last colonoscopy was in July 2015 with findings of diverticulosis in the sigmoid with luminal narrowing. She also has reflux disease for which she has been taking PPI on a daily basis. She was discharged home on antibiotics and apparently notes improvement in symptoms. We did discuss differential diagnosis of ischemic colitis versus diverticulitis, less likely to be infectious colitis. Stool for C. difficile was ordered but it was not sent as she is not able to produce a liquid stool. I did recommend that if she does have liquid stools then proceed with the C. difficile testing and schedule an EGD and colonoscopy in 4 weeks time. Risks and benefits of procedure were discussed in detail.

Luis Torres is a 66 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. A 66-year-old male presents to the clinic for follow-up and to establish care for alcoholic cirrhosis. The patient is accompanied by his daughters. He was reportedly diagnosed with alcoholic cirrhosis in March 2025 at Methodist Baytown. He reports cessation of alcohol consumption since December 2024. Since the diagnosis, he has experienced recurrent admissions to the emergency room for fluid buildup in the abdomen, described as ascites, as well as for anxiety. During these hospitalizations for therapeutic paracentesis, approximately five liters of ascitic fluid were removed each time. The last paracentesis was performed about one and a half months ago, during which four to five liters of fluid were drained. He reports that he is now re-accumulating fluid. The symptoms of fluid retention, including abdominal distension and swelling, have a significant impact on his daily life, causing discomfort and requiring frequent medical interventions. He also reports feeling malnourished. He is currently prescribed lactulose three times daily for hepatic encephalopathy, which has been titrated by his family to manage bowel movements, aiming for a balance as he also experiences constipation. His daughters report he has approximately four to ten bowel movements per day. Due to constipation, MiraLAX has also been added to his regimen. He has a history of two episodes of hepatic encephalopathy. His current diuretic regimen includes furosemide 40 milligrams daily. Spironolactone was discontinued two weeks ago during a hospitalization on the advice of a cardiologist due to a heart condition. The plan was to follow up with his outpatient cardiologist before restarting spironolactone, but this appointment has not yet occurred. The patient's daughters also inquired about his eligibility for a liver transplant. The patient denies hematemesis, melena, hematochezia, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, dysphagia, odynophagia, fecal urgency, unexplained weight loss, fever, and chills. An upper endoscopy performed one month ago for variceal screening was normal. A colonoscopy performed seven months ago was also normal. Based on recent laboratory results from 08/30/2025, with a creatinine of 1.39, his Model for End-Stage Liver Disease score was calculated to be 25.
The past medical history is significant for asthma, alcoholic cirrhosis with ascites, diabetes mellitus, pancreatitis, and benign prostatic hyperplasia.
